comms_internal: Interestingly, the ‘hands’ are syntactically represented as the object, even though the verb seems to be intransitive, cf.: “dest-î çep=im bon-î gazoɫ=î lê-d-ê” [hand-IZF left=OBL.1SG smell-IZF gasoline=OBL.3SG PREV-come.PRS.3SG] ‘my left hand smells gasoline’. (I understand it is lit. ‘My left hand, the smell of gasoline comes of it’) and even “to bon-î gazoɫ=it lê-d-ê” [you smell-IZF gasoline=OBL.2SG PREV-come.PRS-3SG] ‘you smell like gasoline’.

Same as 106. Lit. ‘The lightning gave (it) to the house’. The =OBL.1SG clitic signals possession, and the =OBL.3SG clitic signals the subject ('the lightning'). The preposition can also migrate to the verb, in which case it functions as a prefix and accommodates the subject clitic: “min maɫ-eke=m brîŝke lê=î-da-Ø” [I house-DEF=OBL.1SG lightning PREV=OBL.3SG-give.PST-3SG] ‘Lightning hit my house’.
